natural problem: In how many ways can I choose 4 different officers (President, Vice President, Treasurer, and Secretary) from a club of 9 people?
natural solution: When choosing officers, order matters. The first position can be any of the 9 people. The second position can be any of the remaining 8 people, and so on. The answer is $9\times 8\times 7\times 6=\boxed{3024}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 9"
shows  "fact n div (fact (n - 4)) = 3024"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In how many ways can I choose 4 different officers (President, Vice President, Treasurer, and Secretary) from a club of 9 people? The final Answer is 3024
 ### Proof
 When choosing officers, order matters. The first position can be any of the 9 people. The second position can be any of the remaining 8 people, and so on. The answer is $9\times 8\times 7\times 6=\boxed{3024}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 9"
shows  "fact n div (fact (n - 4)) = 3024"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the result when the factorial of 9 is divided by the factorial of 5. The final answer is 3024.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 9"
shows  "fact n div (fact (n - 4)) = 3024"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In how many ways can I choose 4 different officers (President, Vice President, Treasurer, and Secretary) from a club of 9 people? The final Answer is 3024
 ### Proof
 When choosing officers, order matters. The first position can be any of the 9 people. The second position can be any of the remaining 8 people, and so on. The answer is $9\times 8\times 7\times 6=\boxed{3024}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 9"
shows  "fact n div (fact (n - 4)) = 3024"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: "What is the value of 9 factorial divided by the factorial of 9 minus 4? The final answer is 3024."

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = fact 9 div (fact (9 - 4))"
shows  "n = 3024"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In how many ways can I choose 4 different officers (President, Vice President, Treasurer, and Secretary) from a club of 9 people? The final Answer is 3024
 ### Proof
 When choosing officers, order matters. The first position can be any of the 9 people. The second position can be any of the remaining 8 people, and so on. The answer is $9\times 8\times 7\times 6=\boxed{3024}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = fact 9 div (fact (9 - 4))"
shows  "n = 3024"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Calculate the value of the factorial of 9 divided by the factorial of (9 - 4). The final answer is 3024.

 proof-

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n r :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 9"
and h1 : "r = 4"
and h2 : "r \<le> n"
shows  "fact n div (fact r * fact (n - r)) = 3024"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In how many ways can I choose 4 different officers (President, Vice President, Treasurer, and Secretary) from a club of 9 people? The final Answer is 3024
 ### Proof
 When choosing officers, order matters. The first position can be any of the 9 people. The second position can be any of the remaining 8 people, and so on. The answer is $9\times 8\times 7\times 6=\boxed{3024}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n r :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 9"
and h1 : "r = 4"
and h2 : "r \<le> n"
shows  "fact n div (fact r * fact (n - r)) = 3024"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Calculate the binomial coefficient "9 choose 4". The final answer is 3024.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes people :: nat and choices :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "people = 9"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. choices n = n * choices (n - 1)"
and h2 : "choices 0 = 1"
shows  "choices people = 3024"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In how many ways can I choose 4 different officers (President, Vice President, Treasurer, and Secretary) from a club of 9 people? The final Answer is 3024
 ### Proof
 When choosing officers, order matters. The first position can be any of the 9 people. The second position can be any of the remaining 8 people, and so on. The answer is $9\times 8\times 7\times 6=\boxed{3024}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes people :: nat and choices :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "people = 9"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. choices n = n * choices (n - 1)"
and h2 : "choices 0 = 1"
shows  "choices people = 3024"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Consider a situation where there are 9 people. Each person has a number of choices equal to their number times the choices of the previous person. The first person (0th person) has 1 choice. How many choices does the 9th person have? The final answer is 3024.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n r :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 9"
and h1 : "r = 4"
shows  "fact n div (fact r * fact (n - r)) = 3024"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In how many ways can I choose 4 different officers (President, Vice President, Treasurer, and Secretary) from a club of 9 people? The final Answer is 3024
 ### Proof
 When choosing officers, order matters. The first position can be any of the 9 people. The second position can be any of the remaining 8 people, and so on. The answer is $9\times 8\times 7\times 6=\boxed{3024}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n r :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 9"
and h1 : "r = 4"
shows  "fact n div (fact r * fact (n - r)) = 3024"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Calculate the binomial coefficient for $n = 9$ and $r = 4$, which is given by the formula $\frac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}$. The final answer is $3024$.
